facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 109 of 1954 was filed by special leave from the judgment dated April 21, 1950 of Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 135 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 109 of 1954. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 21, 1950, of the former Nagpur High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 135 of 1949.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J. on October 7, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. October 7. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR J.-This is an appeal against the judgment of the High Court of Nagpur in a reference under s. 66

facts.text: Respondent received Rs. 2,50,000 on August 2, 1941.

anchor.surface_text: the point that is raised for our determination is whether a sum of Rs. 2,50,000 received by the respondent on August 2, 1941, is chargeable to income- tax.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal held that Rs. 2,50,000 was a trading receipt liable to tax, affirming ITO and AAC.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal held, affirming the decisions of the Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, that the amount in question was a trading receipt, and was income liable to be assessed.

facts.text: Nagpur High Court (Sen and Deo JJ) held Rs. 2,50,000 was capital receipt not liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The reference was heard by Sen and Deo, JJ., who held, disagreeing with the Tribunal, that the sum of Rs. 2,50,000 was a capital receipt in the hands of the respondent, and that it, was number liable to be taxed.

facts.text: Special leave under Art. 136 granted by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter applied to this Court for special leave under Art. 136, and the same was granted, and hence this appeal.

facts.text: Respondent is a businessman running railway contracts, rice mill, sugar factory, supplier of limestone and dolomite.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a businessman whose trading activities run in several channels. He is a railway companytractor he runs a rice mill and a sugar factory he is a supplier Of limestone and dolomite.

facts.text: Respondent acquired quarry at Paraghat and sold limestone to Bengal Iron Company Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent had acquired a quarry at Paraghat and had been himself working it and selling limestone quarried out of it to, among others, a Company called the Bengal Iron Company, Ltd.

facts.text: Agreement dated January 5, 1935 between respondent and Bengal Iron Company for all requirements of limestone and dolomite.

anchor.surface_text: On January 5, 1935, the said Company entered into an agreement with the respondent for the purchase of all its requirements of limestone and dolomite from  1  1935 A.C. 431.

facts.text: Agreement modified by another dated December 21, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: and these rates were subsequently modified by another agreement between the parties dated December 21, 1935.

facts.text: Bengal Iron Company went into liquidation in 1936; assets taken over by Indian Iron and Steel Company Ltd on September 8, 1936.

anchor.surface_text: In 1936 the Company went into liquidation, and its assets and liabilities were taken over by another Company called the Indian Iron and Steel Company, Ltd. under a scheme of amalgamation dated September 8, 1936.

facts.text: Indian Iron and Steel Co gave notice dated May 29, 1939 to purchase from other sources due to uneconomic rates.

anchor.surface_text: but later on, finding that the rates were uneconomic owing to increase in the railway freight, it decided to purchase its requirements from other sources, and by numberice dated May 29, 1939, informed the respondent accordingly.

facts.text: Respondent filed Suit No. 211 of 1940 in Calcutta High Court for specific performance and injunction granted on March 13, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the respondent filed Suit No. 211 of 1940 in the High Court of Calcutta for specific performance of the companytract dated January 5, 1935, as modified on December 21, 1935, and for an injunction... and on March 13, 1940, an injunction in those terms was actually issued against the Company.

facts.text: Settlement agreement dated May 9, 1940: respondent to work Gangapur quarry for 25 years, supply limestone to Company.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the Company and the respondent entered into an agreement in settlement of all the disputes between them, and the same was embodied in a document dated May 9, 1940. ... Under this agreement, the respondent was to work a quarry of the Company at a place called Gangapur for a period of 25 years

facts.text: Under May 9, 1940 agreement, Rs. 4,000 per month for 18 months, then Rs. 2-9-0 per ton.

anchor.surface_text: It was expected that it would take 18 months before the siding companyld be companypleted, and it was agreed that during that period the respondent was to be paid Rs. 4,000 every month. Thereafter, the respondent was to be paid at the rate of Rs. 2-9-0 per ton of limestone

facts.text: Railway authorities did not agree to siding at Gangapur.

anchor.surface_text: To companytinue the narration, the railway authorities did number agree to the companystruction at Gangapur of a siding and a loopline to the quarry, and so it became impossible to carry out the agreement

facts.text: New agreement dated August 2, 1941 terminating May 9, 1940 contract; Company to pay Rs. 2,50,000 as solatium plus balance monthly payments.

anchor.surface_text: and on August 2,1941, entered into a new agreement... The agreement recites that the Company feeling difficulty...  1  that the Company should pay Rs. 2,50,000 to the sellers as solatium besides the monthly instalments of Rs. 4,000 , remaining unpaid under the companytract dated May 9, 1940

facts.text: August 2, 1941 agreement also provided new 12-year contracts for limestone supply and iron ore loading at Monoharpore from Jan 1, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: 2  that the Company should take all the limestone required for its furnaces at Kulti from the respondent for a period of 12 years...  3  that the respondent was to be appointed the loading companytractors of the Company for loading all iron ore at Monoharpore for a period of 12 years from January 1, 1942

facts.text: Rs. 2,50,000 was paid to respondent pursuant to August 2, 1941 agreement.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to this agreement, the respondent was paid a sum of Rs. 2,50,000 and the two agreements relating to the purchase of limestone and the loading of iron ore at Monoharpore were also executed.

facts.text: Respondent claimed capital expenses exceeding Rs. 4 lakhs on 1935 contract works, but no evidence provided.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Radha Binode Pal... argued that... the respondent had executed works of a capital nature... exceeding Rs. 4 lakhs ... But have those facts been established ? ... There was numberallegation that capital expenses had been incurred... number is there any evidence on that question.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Rs. 2,50,000 is revenue receipt chargeable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: On a companysideration of all the facts established, we are of opinion that the receipt of Rs. 2,50,000 by the respondent is a revenue receipt. and is chargeable to tax.

facts.text: Respondent had been supplying limestone and dolomite to Bengal Iron Company from about 1920.

anchor.surface_text: The record shows that he had been supplying limestone and dolomite to the Bengal Iron Company, Ltd., from about the year 1920

arguments.claim: No single infallible test for capital vs revenue; depends on facts, question of law

anchor.surface_text: The question whether a receipt is capital or income has frequently come up for determination before the courts. Various rules have been enunciated as furnishing a key to the solution of the question, but as often observed by the highest authorities, it is not possible to lay down any single test as infallible

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of all the facts established, we are of opinion that the receipt of Rs. 2,50,000 by the respondent is a revenue receipt. and is chargeable to tax.

holdings.text: We must hold that the sum of Rs. 2,50,000 was not paid as compensation for expenses thrown away and cannot be held to be a capital receipt on that account.

anchor.surface_text: We must hold that the sum of Rs. 2,50,000 was not paid as compensation for expenses thrown away and cannot be held to be a capital receipt on that account.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No allegation or evidence of capital expenses incurred; Paraghat quarry abandoned prior to 1940 contract; respondent's own statement links payment to 1935 not 1940 contract.

holdings.text: On these facts, it is impossible to come to any conclusion other than that the contract in question was entered into by the respondent in the ordinary course of his business.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, it is impossible to come to any conclusion other than that the contract in question was entered into by the respondent in the ordinary course of his business. The learned Judges in the-Court below observe that the assessee was not a dealer in, though he was a supplier of, limestone.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent supplied limestone since 1920; 1935 contracts continuation; 1940 contract settlement thereof; new 12-year supply contract under 1941 agreement.

holdings.text: Such a contract is part of the business itself, not anything outside it as is the agency, and any receipt on account of such a contract can only be a trading receipt.

anchor.surface_text: Such a contract is part of the business itself, not anything outside it as is the agency, and any receipt on account of such a contract can only be a trading receipt. That there is a distinction between an agency agreement and a contract made in the usual course of business will further be clear,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agency facilitates business (capital); trading contract is the business yielding profits (revenue); cannot analogize assignment in trading context.

holdings.text: when once it is found that a contract was entered into in the ordinary course of business, any compensation received for its termination would be a revenue receipt, irrespective of whether its performance was to consist of a single act or a series of acts spread over a period, and in this respect, it differs from an agency agreement.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Duration does not alter character; examples of single delivery, installments, or ongoing supply all yield revenue on termination; distinguished from agency precedents.

holdings.text: We are accordingly unable to agree that the present case is governed by the decision in Van Den Berghs Ltd. v. Clark.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Van den Berghs involved collateral profit-making structure regulating activities; here agreement itself is the business of quarrying/supplying limestone.

holdings.text: The principle of these decisions has no application where the compensation paid is in respect of rights arising under a trading contract.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Glenboig involves external sterilisation of capital asset by overriding power; here voluntary settlement of trading rights under contract, not prevention of business.

holdings.text: On a consideration of all the facts established, we are of opinion that the receipt of Rs. 2,50,000 by the respondent is a revenue receipt. and is chargeable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: On a consideration of all the facts established, we are of opinion that the receipt of Rs. 2,50,000 by the respondent is a revenue receipt. and is chargeable to tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trading contract in ordinary business; termination compensation is revenue; rejected capital claims; distinguished agency/long-term/sterilisation precedents.

holdings.text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the order of the Tribunal restored.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the order of the Tribunal restored.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred in holding capital receipt; Tribunal correctly found trading receipt taxable.

anchor.surface_text: In Kelsalls case 1 , the assessee carried on business as commission agents and acquired a number of agencies in the course of that business.

precedents.case_name: Kelsall Parsons & Co. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: compensation for termination of one agency among many is revenue receipt
precedents.cited_holding: it was incidental to that agency that it should be modified, altered or discharged

precedents.citation: The Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras v. The South India Pictures Ltd., Karaikudi 5

anchor.surface_text: All these cases were considered by this Court in The Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras v. The South India Pictures Ltd., Karaikudi 1 . There, the assessee was carrying on business in the distribution of films

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax and Excess Profits Tax, Madras v. South India Pictures Ltd., Karaikudi
precedents.cited_proposition: termination payment for film distribution contracts is revenue receipt
precedents.cited_holding: it was the latter and was liable to be taxed

precedents.citation: Golden Horse Shoe, New Ltd. v. Thurgood 1

anchor.surface_text: The principle was thus stated by Romer, L. J., in Golden Horse Shoe, New Ltd. v. Thurgood 1 The determining factor must be the nature of the trade in which the asset is employed.

precedents.case_name: Golden Horse Shoe (New) Ltd. v. Thurgood
precedents.cited_proposition: determining factor whether asset is fixed or circulating capital depends on nature of trade
precedents.cited_holding: The determining factor must be the nature of the trade in which the asset is employed.

anchor.surface_text: Vide Beak v. Robson 1 . The reason is that it is a payment made not on account of profits which might have been earned in the carrying on of the business but as solatium for not carrying on the business.

precedents.cited_proposition: compensation for agreement not to carry on competing business after termination is capital

anchor.surface_text: Vide Thompson v. Magnesium Elektron, Ltd. 2 . It might also happen that one of the parties to the contract might have, in the carrying out -thereof, incurred expenses of a capital character

precedents.cited_proposition: payment to operate during period of contract restricting competition is revenue

precedents.citation: The Glenboig Union Fireclay Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioners of Inland Revenue 1

anchor.surface_text: The decision in The Glenboig Union Fireclay Co. Ltd. v. The Commissioners Of Inland Revenue 1 applies to this category of cases. There, the assessee was carrying on business in the manufacture of fire clay goods

precedents.case_name: Glenboig Union Fireclay Co. Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: compensation for sterilisation of capital asset by statutory authority is capital receipt
precedents.cited_holding: the compensation was really the price paid for sterilising the asset from which otherwise profit might have been obtained

precedents.citation: The Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Newcastle Breweries Ltd. 2

anchor.surface_text: Vide The Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Newcastle Breweries Ltd. 2 . The principle of these decisions has no application where the compensation paid is in respect of rights arising under a trading contract.

precedents.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Newcastle Breweries Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: compensation for injury to stock-in-trade is revenue receipt

justification_sets.label: Fixed Capital vs Circulating Capital support
Agency Contract vs Trading Contract support

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the order of the Tribunal restored.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside; Tribunal order restored; Rs. 2,50,000 held as revenue receipt chargeable to tax.
